description.text: An almost nude caucasian blond woman is standing in a fountain duringt the night. The moon shines. she is barely covered with a transparent cloth and hold her right hand up to touch the water of the fountain while gazing at the viewer. Next to her is a white swan. The background seems tropical, flowers blooming all over. Two smaller swans swim in the back.

inscription.text: With compliments from the Delhi Calender Mfg.Co., High-Class Calendar and Advertising Novelty Manufacturers. (la)

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

ext:item.ext:value: text-en: With compliments from the Delhi Calender Mfg.Co., High-Class Calendar and Advertising Novelty Manufacturers. (la)

description-en: An almost nude caucasian blond woman is standing in a fountain duringt the night. The moon shines. she is barely covered with a transparent cloth and hold her right hand up to touch the water of the fountain while gazing at the viewer. Next to her is a white swan. The background seems tropical, flowers blooming all over. Two smaller swans swim in the back. (la)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: This calendar seems to be a gift from a calendar manufacturing company based in Delhi. Interesting is the link between their self-claimed "high-class"-production and the image. At first being "high-class" is linked to a white or fair skin. Moreover, this image is overtly sexually loaded. Not only the scantily-clad woman on the image points to that fact. Water and also the swan, which stands for gracefulness and beauty have an erotic connotation. Back in 1940s the portrayal of an Indian woman in such a manner would have not been possible for that purpose. According to Jann Dark Indian mass media have constructed the Western woman as an immoral counterpart to the virtuous Indian woman. Projecting sexuality onto an alleged "Other" is a very common practice in many socities as e.g. Irvin Schick has proven for the European context. Sexuality, which is seen as being outside of the own culture does not threaten the own values. (la)
related literature: Loyo, Hilaria 2007. "Blinding Blondes: Whiteness, Femininity, and Stardom." In W.Everett (Ed.): Questions of Colour in Cinema, Frankfurt/M etc.: Peter Lang: 179-196. (la)

related literature: Jah, Sonora & Mara Adelmann 2009. Looking for Love in All the White Places: A Study of Skin Color Preferences on Indian Matrimonial and Mate-Seeking Websites. In Studies in South Asian Film and Media Volume 1, Number 1, 2009,p. 65-83.
related literature: Schick, Irvin C. 1999. The Erotic Margin. Sexuality and Spatiality in Alteritist Discourse. London: Verso.
related literature: Dyer, Richard 1997. White. New York and London: Routledge.

related literature: Dark, Jann 2008. Crossing the Pale. Representations of White Western Women in Indian Film and Media. In Transforming Cultures eJournal, Vol. 3 No 1, February 2008, http://epress.lib.uts.edu.au/journals/TfC
Dyer, Richard 1997. White. New York and London: Routledge.
Schick, Irvin C. 1999. The Erotic Margin. Sexuality and Spatiality in Alteritist Discourse. London: Verso.

Dark, Jann 2008. Crossing the Pale. Representations of White Western Women in Indian Film and Media. In Transforming Cultures eJournal, Vol. 3 No 1, February 2008, http://epress.lib.uts.edu.au/journals/TfC
Loyo, Hilaria 2007. "Blinding Blondes: Whiteness, Femininity, and Stardom." In W.Everett (Ed.): Questions of Colour in Cinema, Frankfurt/M etc.: Peter Lang: 179-196.

Jah, Sonora & Mara Adelmann 2009. Looking for Love in All the White Places: A Study of Skin Color Preferences on Indian Matrimonial and Mate-Seeking Websites. In Studies in South Asian Film and Media Volume 1, Number 1, 2009,p. 65-83.

This calendar seems to be a gift from a calendar manufacturing company based in Delhi. Interesting is the link between their self-claimed "high-class"-production and the image. At first being "high-class" is linked to a white or fair skin. Moreover, this image is overtly sexually loaded. Not only the scantily-clad woman on the image points to that fact. Water and also the swan, which stands for gracefulness and beauty have an erotic connotation. Back in 1940s the portrayal of an Indian woman in such a manner would have not been possible for that purpose. According to Jann Dark Indian mass media have constructed the Western woman as an immoral counterpart to the virtuous Indian woman. Projecting sexuality onto an alleged "Other" is a very common practice in many socities as e.g. Irvin Schick has proven for the European context. Sexuality, which is seen as being outside of the own culture does not threaten the own values.
